FEATURED NEWS

Page Speed Tips and Tools — Speed Up Your Website Today

The speed at which web pages load is an important facet of a business’s website performance. Recent studies indicate that users have high expectations and little patience for slow-loading web pages, which is why it is crucial to use the tools at your disposal to track your website’s performance. In this article, Justia engineer Nick Moline offers a variety of tips to both track and manage web page load speeds to ensure visitors can quickly access the content they’re looking for on your website.

Tech News

Social Media Giants Making Progress on Illegal Hate Speech Takedowns: EC

The European Commission recently announced that there has been “significant progress” over the past six months in taking down illegal hate speech on the large social media outlets—including Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, and Microsoft—in large part due to their implementation of a voluntary Code of Conduct prohibiting such speech on their platforms. The EU defines illegal hate speech as the public incitement to violence or hatred on the basis of certain characteristics, including race, color, religion, descent and national or ethnic origin.

Blocked Trump Twitter Followers Claim First Amendment Violation

Several Twitter users have sent a letter to President Trump asking him to unblock them from his verified Twitter account. The users argue that by blocking them, the president is excluding them from a public forum based on their viewpoint, in violation of the First Amendment of the U.S. Constitution. According to the Wall Street Journal, there is little case law on the issue, and it is not clear as a matter of law whether social media accounts such as Facebook pages or Twitter accounts constitute public forums for the purposes of the First Amendment.

Can Words Kill? Michelle Carter Is Guilty of Manslaughter in Texting Suicide Case

A Massachusetts judge found a young woman guilty of involuntary manslaughter for sending text messages to her boyfriend encouraging him to commit suicide. In general, mere words are insufficient to establish criminal liability for inciting another to commit suicide, but the judge in this case found the facts—particularly the woman’s text instructing him to “get back in” the truck where lethal fumes ultimately caused his death—supported an involuntary manslaughter conviction. The decision raises interesting questions about the scope of legal responsibility and causation.

Right to Speak Freely About Engineering is Subject of 1st Amendment Lawsuit

An Oregon man who was fined by the state engineering board for allegedly practicing engineering without a license has sued on First Amendment grounds. The plaintiff, who has an engineering degree from Sweden, had been engaged in a research and advocacy campaign to elongate yellow traffic light times. The state board, which has fined as many as six other individuals for similar activities, has agreed to lift the restriction on the plaintiff referring to himself as an “engineer” while the lawsuit is pending.

Does First Amendment Protect Augmented Reality Games Like Pokémon Go? Suit Raises the Issue

In response to a Milwaukee County ordinance requiring permits for game makers before augmented reality technology apps can be used in public parks, developer Candy Labs has sued on First Amendment grounds. The developer argues that restricting augmented reality games such as Pokémon Go in this manner constitutes a prior restraint on its speech, is unconstitutionally vague, and restricts speech on the basis of content. The County responds that in this case the First Amendment does not protect games that do not convey messages or ideas.

EU Reportedly Ready to Fine Google Billions in Shopping Search Antitrust Case

After months of anticipation, the EU has leveled a hefty fine at Google for alleged abuses of power related to shopping search. While the fine has been expected for some time, the $2.7 billion amount was larger than expected. The search giant is accused of favoring Google Shopping results over other content. Google maintains that its results were beneficial to users, and plans to study the decision before determining next steps. In the meantime, at least two other antitrust matters are currently pending against Google.

Uber Founder Travis Kalanick Resigns as C.E.O.

Last month, Travis Kalanick resigned as CEO of the ride-hailing service Uber. Kalanick helped found Uber in 2009, as well as build it into the wildly popular and successful company it is today. He stepped down under pressure after a shareholder revolt made it infeasible to stay on, capping months of inquiries over Uber’s leadership and widespread criticism of the Silicon Valley startup culture it helped develop.

SEO News

Google to Block Some Ads in Chrome -- Even Its Own

Google makes a great deal of its money from online ads. In 2018, however, Chrome browser users will start to see fewer of them as Google begins to block ads that attempt to get your attention in more aggressive or annoying ways--including Google’s own ads that fall under this new criteria. The company’s new philosophy is that fewer annoying ads are preferable to no ads at all. Soon enough, Chrome will no longer show ads on websites that don’t comply with the Better Ads standards, including those that Google itself owns or serves.

Google is Speeding Up Search Ads With AMP Technology

Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) is an open-source project that speeds up mobile web pages. Now, Google is aiming to bring that speed to search ads. A new beta will launch for Google Adwords that will let advertisers use AMP pages as landing pages. Google is also converting a number of ads on AMP pages served across the Google Display Network to this new AMP ad format, which is said to load five seconds faster than regular ads, without losing any visual clarity.

Is AMP the Answer to Format Fragmentation?

Format fragmentation is increasingly burdening news publishers. Facebook aims to overcome this by adding Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) to its Instant Articles toolkit. AMP offers flexibility in a non-proprietary format. Most publishers now accept AMP, making it a solid choice for Facebook and other platforms.

Accelerated Mobile Pages vs. Facebook Instant Articles: Is Google Winning the Mobile War?

While there has been some resistance against the adoption of Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) from standard mobile page proponents, the proof appears to be in the numbers. Articles published with Accelerated Mobile Pages load as much as four times faster and boast an improvement in engagement time of 35%, according to one study.

The Periodic Table of SEO Success Factors 2017 Edition Now Released

The updated fourth edition of Search Engine Land’s Periodic Table of SEO Success Factors has now been released. The table consists of 35 factors, each of which has a specific weight, that work together in contributing to or detracting from a website’s SEO success. While no new factors were added for 2017, some had increases or decreases in weight, and a small number were dropped. Factors with increased importance in this edition included mobile-friendliness and speed.

Social Media News

Write a LinkedIn Message That Will Get a Response

LinkedIn is a valuable tool for making industry connections, and utilizing its messaging capabilities can help you take your networking efforts one step further. This article provides a few brief pointers for crafting messages that will catch the recipient’s attention, highlight what you can offer them, and help you continue to grow your network.

How to Engage Prospects on LinkedIn: A 5-Step Plan for Better Leads

This step-by-step guide can help LinkedIn users more effectively engage prospective clients and customers. Featured strategies include using a profile summary that conveys your value and experience, using the LinkedIn feed to circulate your own content as well as that of others, and developing scripts for reaching out to users you hope to connect with.

6 Interesting Ways You Can Use Twitter Polls

Twitter can be a valuable means of engaging followers, educating them about your business, and increasing your visibility. Ways you can utilize the social media platform’s polls feature include conducting product research, developing industry statistics, surveying opinions about public events, and promoting content.

Legal Industry News

New Mexico’s Top Court Should Acknowledge Excessive PD Workloads and Craft Remedy, ABA Says

The ABA has filed a brief with the New Mexico Supreme Court in support of a petition by the state public defender’s office encouraging the high court to address and rectify excessive public defender workloads. The petition seeks, among other things, an order that private lawyers represent indigent clients for free or that court clerks stop accepting cases alleging minor drug crimes. Concerns about competent representation by overworked attorneys contributed to the ABA’s involvement in the case.

Does California Make It Too Difficult to Pass the Bar? Two Profs Link Low Scores to Ethics Issues

Deans from 20 ABA-accredited law schools in California have asked the state supreme court to consider lowering the required multistate bar exam score required to pass the test. California’s minimum required score is the highest in the nation next to Delaware, and its bar passage rates have been dismally low in recent years. Some point to the declining credentials of incoming students or millennials’ study habits as alternative explanations for the drop in bar exam success rates. Others in the academic world also argue that lower bar scores lead to a greater likelihood of professional discipline issues, presenting a possible counterargument to the notion that minimum score requirements should be lowered.

Should Tech Training For Lawyers Be Mandatory?

With the impacts of technology on the legal profession becoming more apparent each day, and over half of all states mandating tech competence for lawyers, this column considers whether other states should follow Florida’s lead in making tech MCLE training a requirement for all attorneys.

The Ethics of Crowdfunding for Lawyers: Uncharted Territory or Familiar Terrain?

Crowdfunding represents another opportunity for lawyers to reshape the legal practice world through tech, though this method of funding isn't without its ethical risks. But are these actually new risks, or does crowdfunding simply call on lawyers to apply established ethics rules to new technology? This piece in Justia’s Verdict column explores those questions and reviews recent ethics opinions on the subject.

New ABA Email Guidelines: How Can Lawyers Comply?

The ABA recently released a new opinion providing guidance to attorneys on secure client communication. Though the consensus among legal tech commentators is that this complex opinion is not especially user-friendly from a practical standpoint, this column argues that the simple solution is to implement a standardized communication process that provides secure encryption for most case-related communications. It also provides recommendations for securing other modes of communication, including phone calls and text messages.

Recent cases involving expert witness testimony:


Radiology Expert Witness Allowed to Testify in Murder Case

A Radiology Expert Witness was allowed to testify that the fatal injuries suffered by the victim were a result of severe trauma, and not accidental.


Plaintiff's Police Procedure Expert Testifies on Coercive Interrogation

The court allowed a Police Procedures Expert Witness to testify in a murder case involving allegations of false confessions.


Ninth Circuit Reverses Ruling on Pathology and Oncology Experts

An Oncology Expert Witness and a Pathology Expert Witness were allowed to testify when the appellate court looked broadly at their methodology.
